posts.body:
>>a7ea0a67-8b82-4ed1-9cf4-ec916e1c32e6

It only downloads thumbnails by default.

>>a2769bc8-d143-4036-aa70-d34cc7992d5f
It's about as editable as you can get on a decentralized site.

Anyone running the default client will pick up the new version, and that will be that.

If you had a modified client you could keep track of any updates you see.

>>48d95a07-e2b0-4ace-aaf1-d68c9cfd50bc
It's about as powerful as tripcodes.

>>0b958775-8e02-4d9e-9de2-1a730a6d88cb
Removes mutes, then. They aren't gone gone, but you have to copy them manually to get them enabled again.

Most noticeable with boards.

do you even diffract?

Or, a little more seriously, _everything_ (well ok, not Bessel beams, but those require infinitely wide beams) is inverse-square in the far field.

>>c34626a6-e86c-43fb-938a-a66e0940e24d

I managed to get it up and running with the tor package, not on Arch though.

You need to go into torrc and make sure both the control and socks proxy is enabled, and set up authentication.

>>073f2a58-4314-41d7-9ee6-cc3f534b8571
...which brings up a popup asking to hide all content from that specific address.

Nowhere I can paste that list, so far as I can tell.

>>55c4b25f-d0a5-4e20-803d-ab223f3413fb
That could be doable. Killer on slower boards though. What to do about thread thumbnails?

>>6b29994d-ec29-455b-9658-eaa85801be48
> multiple trusted modstreams users can subscribe to, instead of a single faggot BO controlling the whole board forever.
Agreed.
>Also full disk encryption 
It's running on an encrypted partition anyhow, but better protection of data at rest is seldom a bad thing.

>>49317d5d-471a-4ad9-b0d2-340363b61a46

Options (top left) -> click on entry in blacklist -> top right "Remove QResearch from blacklist? ok"

>>879fb24f-bd88-474c-9a00-21cdd5592b2d

The board is at the end of the blacklist entry. E.g. "users/17rEeDwJ1UrHPHSrqspzTQJVPAFFxK8xtS:QResearch"

>>805d2ca7-6f38-4811-bea6-84de334087b5
The biggest push away from darknets to many was the network effect. "I'd join if everyone else was".

Kill the old site and suddenly it's much easier.
It's about as hard to spoof this as it is to spoof tripcodes.
Expose tripcodes, and make it easier to change identities.

>>f631fefe-4cdc-4402-a2d2-990a005ac8c8

'''test'''
~~test~~
''test''
__test__
**test**
==test==
`test`
[test](test)

>>f631fefe-4cdc-4402-a2d2-990a005ac8c8
Interesting. Doesn't match millchan's source.

>>53b206b1-db28-4805-a32e-fe8bb1457340
>it requires the ability to administrate the tor daemon itself
Tor browser does the same.
no

Changing software is a risk.

What fixes does this do?

>>1ce446b2-2b3f-4556-be3d-4a6835fbfe29
They cracked down on it, like usual.

>>840f9d43-67a1-4aa4-b0ea-bb11763e491a
Tor browser normally wants to connect directly to tor.

For ZeroNet, we don't want to do that. We want to go tor_browser->ZeroNet->tor.

So you configure ZeroNet to use tor, and then configure tor_browser to use ZeroNet.

Currently set to 100GB max.

Still deeply in the negative, but I'll get there eventually.

>>9f2738ca-565b-4317-b607-f29e88cd76aa
No longer true.

Forth is very fast... on anything before the P4.

The implicit dependency on the last instruction by stack-based languages is killer for  ILP.

>>bd08e263-3fa1-41f0-8ee5-677159635a74
>Pic related.
Thanks. No security fixes then.

>In the worst scenario
I could care less if the site sucks ass. It's security I mainly care about.

>>f697b50c-54b3-4165-9fb2-50f0216efd11
And not enough people have it pinned to download before OP drops offline, yes.

>>93364500-6218-48b0-b11c-af7f5e4cf233
ZeroNet makes post thumbnails client-side, using the html canvas.

Tor browser blocks the html canvas, as it's way to easy to use for browser fingerprinting.

>>2c6ca1c2-d90a-4b6b-a412-c74a5b4b1513
A barrier to entry helps.

>>b30a153d-fc44-4b6e-b5ae-f74a2d8a089a
Seems so.

>>8f93a35a-cf6c-4751-a51c-cb96a0b4d8f0
...and as usual, this "update" makes the UI worse.

>>19ab98a7-decd-48e3-8aee-d33fce89e611
Lurkers happen.
